body_html:
what @fmassa means is that load_state_dict can easily have subtly different behavior than diff_state_dict. For example, what happens if there are collisions and load_state_dict is resolving them in one way, while diff_state_dict resolves them in another way.

I see @fmassa 's point, but I dont think it's that hard to keep consistent. We just have to refactor the load_state_dict code to use diff_state_dict to infer collisions / duplicates.
body_text:
what @fmassa means is that load_state_dict can easily have subtly different behavior than diff_state_dict. For example, what happens if there are collisions and load_state_dict is resolving them in one way, while diff_state_dict resolves them in another way.
I see @fmassa 's point, but I dont think it's that hard to keep consistent. We just have to refactor the load_state_dict code to use diff_state_dict to infer collisions / duplicates.
body:
what @fmassa means is that `load_state_dict` can easily have subtly different behavior than `diff_state_dict`. For example, what happens if there are collisions and `load_state_dict` is resolving them in one way, while `diff_state_dict` resolves them in another way.

I see @fmassa 's point, but I dont think it's that hard to keep consistent. We just have to refactor the `load_state_dict` code to use `diff_state_dict` to infer collisions / duplicates.
